title: Chronicon Faventinum
text:
The Chronicon Faventinum is a <a href="Latin">Latin</a> chronicle of the city of <a href="Faenza">Faenza</a> and the region of <a href="Emilia-Romagna">Emilia-Romagna</a> from 20 BC until AD 1236. It was begun by a Faentine native, Tolosanus, a <a href="deacon">deacon</a>, "<a href="%3Awikt%3Amagister%23Latin">magister</a>" and later <a href="secular%20canon">secular canon</a> of <a href="Faenza%20Cathedral">Faenza Cathedral</a>. He brought the record down to 1218. The chronicle was subsequently continued for a decade by at least two other anonymous writers, probably canons of the cathedral.
Tolosanus was born in the mid-12th century. He was a <a href="rhetoric">rhetoric</a>ian active in municipal politics and in the local church. He had a <a href="Bible">biblical</a> and <a href="Classics">classical</a> education, an understanding of juridical procedure and good <a href="Latinity">Latinity</a>. He died on 5 April 1226.
The "Chronicon" is the earliest piece of urban historiography from Emilia-Romagna. it is divided into 153 chapters, each headed by a <a href="rubric">rubric</a>. It begins with the mythical founding of the city by the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Romans</a>, which Tolosanus dates to 20 BC. Tolosanus quotes extensively from <a href="Virgil">Virgil</a> and the bible. His work is largely legendary until the period of the <a href="Medieval%20commune">communes</a> (11–12th century). While for the earlier period, his chronology is based on the succession of <a href="bishops%20of%20Faenza">bishops of Faenza</a>, for the communal period it is based on the succession of magistrates.
Ideologically, the "Chronicon" has <a href="Guelphs%20and%20Ghibellines">Guelph</a> (i.e., pro-papal) sympathies. The solidarity of the commune, the clergy and the bishop is stressed. Tolosanus was imbued with a <a href="crusading">crusading</a> spirit and he glorifies the urban "militia". <a href="Imola">Imola</a>, <a href="Forli">Forli</a> and <a href="Ravenna">Ravenna</a> are portrayed as Faenza's traditional enemies. Faenza was always a member of the <a href="Lombard%20League">Lombard League</a>, and the "Chronicon" often rises above local history to cover the wider conflict between the league and the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>. It records how the city sent 27 <a href="knight">knight</a>s to fight for the pope against the emperor during the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Keys">War of the Keys</a> (1228–1230).
